subject: Politics
title: First Past the Post
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on First Past the Post.

hook.text: In first-past-the-post, the candidate with the most votes wins. Simple â€” but it wastes millions of votes.

buildup.text: FPTP is used in the US, UK, and India. Each district elects one winner. All other votes count for nothing.

discovery.text: A candidate can win with just 35% of votes if opponents split the rest. Majority support isn't required.

twist.text: FPTP naturally creates two-party systems. Third parties split votes and rarely win, so voters avoid them.

climax.text: Millions of voters feel unrepresented. Safe seats mean most races are decided before voting starts.

punchline.text: FPTP is simple but unfair. The winner often doesn't have majority support.

quiz.question: Why does first-past-the-post tend to create two-party systems?
options: Third parties split votes and rarely win, so voters avoid them
Laws prohibit more than two parties
Voters naturally prefer only two options
